anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and order dated December 3, 1956, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Letters Patent Appeal No. 25-D of 1956, arising out of the judgment and order dated April 9, 1956, of the said High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 8-D of 1955.

The appellant then moved the Punjab High Court by a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in which his main companysentions were  a  that he had numberopportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him within the meaning of Art. 311  2  of the Constitution and  b  that he had asked for leave preparatory to retirement and accepted service under Albert David Co. Ltd. in the bona fide belief that Government had numberobjection to his accepting such private employment.

This is an appeal by special leave and the only question for decision is if the order of the President dated October 1, 1954, removing the appellant from service with effect from that date is invalid, as claimed by the appellant, by reason of a companytravention of the provisions of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution. The short facts are these.

anchor.surface_text: On June 16, 1953, the appellant was charged with hav- ing violated r. 15 of the Government Servants Conduct Rules and Fundamental Rule 11. Rule 15 of the Government Servants Conduct Rules states, inter alia, that a Government servant may number without the previous sanction of Government engage in any trade or undertake any employment other than his public duties.

anchor.surface_text: violated r. 15 of the Government Servants Conduct Rules and Fundamental Rule 11. Rule 15 of the Government Servants Conduct Rules states, inter alia, that a Government servant may number without the previous sanction of Government engage in any trade or undertake any employment other than his public duties. Fundamental Rule 11 says in effect that unless in any case it be otherwise distinctly provided, the whole time of a Government servant is at the disposal of the Government which pays him.

Reliance on Jatindra Nath Biswas, Dayanidhi Rath, Lakshmi Narain Gupta: show cause notices invalid for not specifying exact punishment or being vague
arguments.court_reasoning: Decisions proceeded on different footings (no second notice, juxtaposed punishments, vague); do not lay down rule that multiple punishments invalidate notice

arguments.claim: certain mistakes of reference in the order of the President dated October 1, 1954 [...] inaccurate references were of any vital importance

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee referred to certain mistakes of reference in the order of the President dated October 1, 1954. Instead of referring to r. 15 of the Government Servants Conduct Rules, r. 13 was referred to.

arguments.court_reasoning: Inaccurate references not of vital importance; order based in effect on violation of r.15 and FR 11

arguments.claim: show cause notice [...] did not contravene [...] Art. 311(2) [...] appellant had a reasonable opportunity

holdings.text: The show cause notice dated April 14, 1954, did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution. The appellant had a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice provisionally opined major penalty by listing three alternatives, enabling representation against proposed action; complies with Khem Chand requirements for opportunity (c); undisputed opportunities (a) and (b).

holdings.text: The enumeration of the other two punishments in the show cause notice gave a better and fuller opportunity to the appellant; nothing wrong in the punishing authority tentatively forming the opinion that the charges proved merit any one of the three major penalties.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Listing alternatives provides fuller chance to contest each; specifying only severest could allow lesser without grievance, but listing enhances fairness.

holdings.text: If Art. 311(2) requires the exact or actual punishment to be mentioned in the show cause notice, a third notice would be necessary if representation accepted, which is against the purpose of the second notice.

anchor.surface_text: Let us examine [...] what consequences will follow if Art. 311 2  requires [...] exact or actual punishment [...] must be mentioned in the show cause notice [...] then a third notice will be necessary

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation: notice allows representation to mitigate proposed punishment; rigid exactness leads to procedural absurdity defeating object.

holdings.text: The decisions in Jatindra Nath Biswas, Dayanidhi Rath and Lakshmi Narain Gupta do not lay down that whenever more than one punishment is mentioned in the second show cause notice, the notice must be held to be bad. If they do, they are incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: We do number, therefore, take these decisions as laying down that whenever more than one punishment is mentioned in the second show cause numberice, the numberice must be held to be bad. If these decisions lay down any such rule, we must hold them to be incorrect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished on facts (no second notice, juxtaposed punishments, vagueness); do not support broad rule against multiple/alternative punishments.

holdings.text: The inaccurate references in the order of the President dated October 1, 1954, were of no vital importance.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the inaccurate references were of any vital importance. In effect and substance the order of removal dated October 1, 1954, was based on the ground that the appellant violated r. 15

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance prevails: order effectively based on r.15 Conduct Rules and FR11 violations, matching enquiry basis.

holdings.text: The real point in I.M. Lall and Khem Chand was absence of second notice after enquiry; observations on 'actual' or 'one of three' punishments must be read in context.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be remembered [...] that both in I. M. Lalls case [...] and Khem Chands case [...] the real point [...] was that no second notice had been given [...] after the enquiry was over

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual reading of precedents: focus on post-enquiry tentative proposal opportunity, not mandating single exact punishment.
